content: Hello again, maybe I've found a solution... When you right-click on a folder, you have a pop-up menu... choose "Properties": a box is opened with title "Folder properties". Below on the right, you find a button called "Repair Folder". When I clicked on it, a new download from the server for all the emails of the folder began, and the size of the corresponding file (e.g., "Inbox") decreased dramatically... It seems that the local copy of emails was deleted, and it was replaced by a much "lighter" copy downloaded again from the server. I think it's lighter because now only message headers are saved on my hard-disk...
creator: denis@beyond.the.river

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
L'eseguibile di Thunderbird e i dati dell'utente (profilo) sono installati in posizioni diverse. È molto improbabile che a danneggiarsi sia l'eseguibile di Thunderbird o i suoi file di appoggio che, nei fatti, non vengono mai modificati dopo l’installazione. Al contrario i file del profilo vengono modificati continuamente da Thunderbird e spesso anche da altri software "intrusi" (per esempio l'antivirus); per cui è più probabile che possano danneggiarsi.

Reinstallando e poi copiando la cartella del profilo rischi di ritrovarti esattamente dove sei adesso. Comunque se vuoi puoi anche provare. Grosso modo la procedura è analoga a quella per il trasferimento di Thunderbird da un computer all'altro spiegata in questa guida -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/trasferire-dati-thunderbird-nuovo-computer

content:
The location of your IMAP account is as shown in attached screenshot. That is a bit unique. To see your files, a screenshot of the 1obgur6I.default folder itself may help, plus a screenshot of the contents of the imapmail.sbd follder, and, if present, a screenshot of the 1obgur6I.default\Mail folder and the 1obgur6I.default\Mail\Local Folders folder. Those should display whatever message folders are there.

Another possibility is that you may have a prior profile, not longer used. You can check that by viewing the 

...appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder to see if other profiles exist. If so, look there for the same folders, such as the Mail and/or imapmail folders.

A comment: the account shown is IMAP. if those folders were removed from the online account, they would no longer appear in Thunderbird.

content: Puzzling. your first post's screenshot of server settings pane is different from your screenshot of same account in second post. There have been problems in the past in the profile's prefs file has multiple copies. The profile is highly non-standard, and I have no idea what has transpired there. My overall suggestion would be to start over and create a fresh profile and set up the accounts fresh. That could be tedious, so I suggest redoing this one account. Since it's IMAP, there is no loss of data. Just remove it, including any data of the account, and then recreate it. A normal setup will put the account into the imapmail folder so that all account entries are together. In the profile you have, the account is in the root of the profile and files are scattered.
creator: davidsk

content:
My experience is that automated backups do not work well with Thunderbird. The safe way to do a backup is to backup the entire profile all at once when thunderbird is not running. That is the best assurance that a restore will work flawlessly. I routinely see posts here where a proprietary backup could not be properly restored and had to be done piecemeal. I'm not a technical guru, but part of the challenge is that thunderbird does not release its hold on files, causing a backup done while thunderbird is running to be incomplete or corrupt. My personal approach is to run a daily backup at a time when I know thunderbird is not running. I also run a standalone backup weekly for safety. I share here my technique:

here is the info in brief steps:

BACKUP

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media

RESTORE

  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
I suggest you log onto your online account to see what is there. Is this a POP account? A possibility is that the archive folder was created as a subfolder of the inbox, which would leave the inbox as still full. You can check this by

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. click either the imapmail folder if IMAP account or the Mail folder for POP
  4. now, click the account folder so the message folders, such as inbox, sent, etc, appear
  5. do a screenshot of that and post back. that will help in assessing and making suggestions on the issue.
creator: davidsk

content:
The passwords can be view by this: - click setting>privacy&security - click the savedpasswords button and then showpasswords button - in doing so, you may be prompted for the PCs initial signin password

the passwords shown are the ones that thunderbird is using. that is, if you are getting 'invalid password' errors, that means that the passwords in thunderbird are no longer correct. in that case, you need to contact the email provider to get a fresh password. Also, if the email account uses a secondary password (such as Gmail), that is not the actual password.
creator: davidsk

content: Hi, Sharon, the PIN in question is whatever password you enter when turning the PC on. Has nothing to do with Thunderbird. In settings>privacy&security, the letters PIN are grey, but you should be able to enter your PC sign in code. However, if you are having errors in signing in, the password stored in thunderbird is no help, as that is the password being rejected. Retrieving it may just be going down a rabbithole. Another possibility is that there may be an error in the account setting. For example, if you changed the email address on account from his to yours, that would explain a password error. Are you able to log onto the account online? Browsers often retain the password that last worked. You might check the saved passwords in your browser or your husband's to see if the password is there. Do look there. Steps to do that vary by browser. If that fails, contacting the email provider's support line may do what you want. They may need some proof of account, and that varies by email provider.
creator: davidsk
